DESCRIPTION: Coroutine that handles WebSocket connections, initializes the game, and processes moves.

```
import json
import logging

from connect4 import Connect4

logging.basicConfig(format="%(message)s", level=logging.DEBUG)

async def handler(websocket):
    # Initialize a Connect Four game.
    game = Connect4()

    try:
        async for message in websocket:
            # Parse a "play" event from the UI.
            event = json.loads(message)
            assert event["type"] == "play"
            column = event["column"]

            try:
                # Play the move.
                row = game.play(column)
            except RuntimeError as exc:
                # Send an "error" event if the move was invalid.
                event = {
                    "type": "error",
                    "message": str(exc),
                }
                await websocket.send(json.dumps(event))
                continue

            # Send a "play" event to update the UI.
            event = {
                "type": "play",
                "player": game.last_player,
                "column": column,
                "row": row,
            }
            await websocket.send(json.dumps(event))

            # If move is winning, send a "win" event.
            if game.winner is not None:
                event = {
                    "type": "win",
                    "player": game.winner,
                }
                await websocket.send(json.dumps(event))
    finally:
        logging.debug("Connection closed")
```

TITLE: WebSocket Server for Counter Application in Python
DESCRIPTION: This Python script implements a WebSocket server that manages a shared counter. It allows clients to increment or decrement the counter and broadcasts updates to all connected clients.
SOURCE: https://github.com/python-websockets/websockets/blob/main/docs/intro/examples.rst#2025-04-20_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# counter.py

import asyncio
import json
import websockets

COUNTER = 0
USERS = set()

def users_event():
    return json.dumps({"type": "users", "count": len(USERS)})

def counter_event():
    return json.dumps({"type": "counter", "value": COUNTER})

async def notify_users():
    if USERS:  # asyncio.wait doesn't accept an empty list
        message = users_event()
        await asyncio.wait([user.send(message) for user in USERS])

async def notify_counter():
    if USERS:  # asyncio.wait doesn't accept an empty list
        message = counter_event()
        await asyncio.wait([user.send(message) for user in USERS])

async def register(websocket):
    USERS.add(websocket)
    await notify_users()

async def unregister(websocket):
    USERS.remove(websocket)
    await notify_users()

async def counter(websocket, path):
    # register(websocket) sends user_event() to websocket
    global COUNTER
    await register(websocket)
    try:
        await websocket.send(counter_event())
        async for message in websocket:
            data = json.loads(message)
            if data["action"] == "+":
                COUNTER += 1
                await notify_counter()
            elif data["action"] == "-":
                COUNTER -= 1
                await notify_counter()
            else:
                print(f"unsupported event: {data}")
    finally:
        await unregister(websocket)

start_server = websockets.serve(counter, "localhost", 6789)

asyncio.get_event_loop().run_until_complete(start_server)
asyncio.get_event_loop().run_forever()
```

TITLE: Implementing a Python WebSockets Echo Server with Health Checks and Graceful Shutdown
DESCRIPTION: A Python implementation of a WebSockets echo server that includes a health check endpoint at '/healthz' and handles SIGTERM signals for graceful shutdown. This server is designed to meet typical requirements for running on a Platform as a Service.
SOURCE: https://github.com/python-websockets/websockets/blob/main/docs/deploy/fly.rst#2025-04-20_snippet_0

```
#!/usr/bin/env python

import asyncio
import os
import signal
import sys

from websockets.server import serve


async def echo(websocket):
    async for message in websocket:
        await websocket.send(message)


async def health_check(path, request_headers):
    if path == "/healthz":
        return http_response("OK")
    return None


def http_response(body, status="200 OK", headers=None):
    if headers is None:
        headers = {}
    if "Content-Length" not in headers:
        headers["Content-Length"] = str(len(body))
    if "Content-Type" not in headers:
        headers["Content-Type"] = "text/plain; charset=utf-8"
    headers_str = "\r\n".join(f"{k}: {v}" for k, v in headers.items())
    return f"HTTP/1.1 {status}\r\n{headers_str}\r\n\r\n{body}"


async def main():
    # Set the stop condition when receiving SIGTERM.
    loop = asyncio.get_running_loop()
    stop = loop.create_future()
    loop.add_signal_handler(signal.SIGTERM, stop.set_result, None)

    port = int(os.environ.get("PORT", "8080"))
    async with serve(
        echo,
        host="",
        port=port,
        process_request=health_check,
    ):
        await stop


if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(main())
```

TITLE: Implementing Publish-Subscribe Pattern for WebSocket Broadcasting in Python
DESCRIPTION: A PubSub class implementation that creates a message stream supporting multiple consumers using asyncio. The stream is implemented as a linked list of futures, allowing consumers to read messages at their own pace without synchronization.
SOURCE: https://github.com/python-websockets/websockets/blob/main/docs/topics/broadcast.rst#2025-04-20_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
class PubSub:
    def __init__(self):
        self.waiter = asyncio.get_running_loop().create_future()

    def publish(self, value):
        waiter = self.waiter
        self.waiter = asyncio.get_running_loop().create_future()
        waiter.set_result((value, self.waiter))

    async def subscribe(self):
        waiter = self.waiter
        while True:
            value, waiter = await waiter
            yield value

    __aiter__ = subscribe

PUBSUB = PubSub()
```

```
async def relay(queue, websocket):

        message = await queue.get()
```

TITLE: WebSocket Server for Broadcasting Django Admin Events
DESCRIPTION: Complete implementation of a WebSocket server that authenticates users, tracks their permissions, subscribes to Redis events, and broadcasts admin events to connected clients based on their permissions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/python-websockets/websockets/blob/main/docs/howto/django.rst#2025-04-20_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# notifications.py
import asyncio
import json
import os

import aioredis
import django
from django.contrib.auth import get_user_model
from django.contrib.contenttypes.models import ContentType
from django.db import connection

from sesame.utils import get_user
from websockets.server import serve

# Initialize Django
os.environ.setdefault("DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE", "<your project>.settings")
django.setup()

User = get_user_model()

# Store active websocket connections with their users and content types.
connections = {}


async def get_content_types(user):
    """Determine which content types a user can view and change."""
    # Close the connection to the database because we're in a long-running process.
    connection.close()

    # Filter content types by user permissions.
    if user.is_superuser:
        # Superusers can view and change all content types.
        view = list(ContentType.objects.values_list("id", flat=True))
        change = view
    else:
        # For regular users, get the content types they can view or change.
        perms = user.get_all_permissions()
        view = [
            ct.id
            for ct in ContentType.objects.all()
            if f"{ct.app_label}.view_{ct.model}" in perms
        ]
        change = [
            ct.id
            for ct in ContentType.objects.all()
            if f"{ct.app_label}.change_{ct.model}" in perms
        ]

    return {"view": view, "change": change}


async def handler(websocket):
    # Receive and validate the token.
    try:
        token = await websocket.recv()
    except Exception:
        await websocket.close(1011, "authentication failed")
        return

    # Authenticate with django-sesame.
    try:
        user = await asyncio.to_thread(get_user, token)
    except Exception:
        await websocket.close(1011, "authentication failed")
        return

    # Check if a user was returned.
    if user is None:
        await websocket.close(1011, "authentication failed")
        return

    # Get content types this user can access.
    content_types = await asyncio.to_thread(get_content_types, user)

    # Store the connection for later broadcast.
    connections[websocket] = (user, content_types)

    # Keep the connection open until the client disconnects.
    try:
        await websocket.wait_closed()
    finally:
        del connections[websocket]


async def events_listener():
    """Listen for events on Redis and broadcast them to clients."""
    redis = await aioredis.create_redis("redis://localhost:6379/1")
    channel = (await redis.subscribe("events"))[0]

    try:
        async for message in channel.iter():
            data = json.loads(message.decode())
            # Find the content type ID for this model
            app_label, model = data["model"].split(".")
            try:
                content_type_id = await asyncio.to_thread(
                    lambda: ContentType.objects.get(
                        app_label=app_label, model=model
                    ).id
                )
            except Exception:
                continue

            # Broadcast to users who can view this content type
            for websocket, (user, content_types) in connections.items():
                if content_type_id in content_types["view"]:
                    try:
                        await websocket.send(json.dumps(data))
                    except Exception:
                        pass
    finally:
        # Clean up resources
        redis.close()
        await redis.wait_closed()


async def main():
    # Start the events listener task
    listener_task = asyncio.create_task(events_listener())
    
    # Start the WebSocket server
    async with serve(handler, "localhost", 8888):
        await asyncio.Future()  # run forever


if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(main())
```
